parameters.name: Book Metadata
parameters.description: Core book information that must be introduced at session start

config.title: Why Nations Fail: The Origins of Power, Prosperity, and Poverty
config.nobelPrize: Awarded 2024 Nobel Prize in Economics for this work on how institutions shape prosperity
config.centralQuestion: Why are some countries rich and others desperately poor?

parameters.name: Core Argument
parameters.description: The central thesis of inclusive vs extractive institutions

config.thesis: Nations succeed or fail based primarily on whether their institutions are inclusive or extractive. This is not about geography, culture, or ignorance - it is about the rules of the game that humans create.

inclusiveInstitutions.definition: Institutions that allow broad participation in economic and political activity
characteristics: Allow broad participation in economic activity
Protect property rights and enforce contracts fairly
Provide public services (education, infrastructure, rule of law)
Distribute political power broadly - pluralism, elections, accountability
Create incentives for innovation, investment, and effort

extractiveInstitutions.definition: Institutions that concentrate power and wealth among a narrow elite
characteristics: Concentrate power and wealth among a narrow elite
Use coercion, monopolies, or corruption to extract resources from the majority
Suppress innovation that threatens the elite's position
Lack accountability - no rule of law, no checks on power

config.keyInsight: Political institutions shape economic institutions. If political power is concentrated, those in power design economic rules to benefit themselves. If political power is distributed, economic rules tend to benefit the many.

parameters.name: Chapter 1: The Nogales Puzzle
parameters.description: The natural experiment of a divided city

config.chapterTitle: So Close and Yet So Different
config.puzzle: Nogales is a single city divided by the US-Mexico border. Same geography, same climate, same culture, same ethnic background.

characteristics: Access to electricity, sewage, public health, roads
Citizens can vote and expect law enforcement to be accountable

config.explanation: The border marks an institutional line, not a natural one. The US side has inclusive political institutions (democracy, rule of law, accountability) that created inclusive economic institutions (property rights, public investment, opportunity). The Mexican side inherited extractive institutions from Spanish colonialism - elite control, weak property rights, corruption - that persisted even after independence.
config.keyQuote: The reason Nogales, Arizona is much richer than Nogales, Sonora is simple: it is because of the very different institutions on the two sides of the border.
config.significance: Nogales is a 'natural experiment' - it isolates the variable of institutions. You cannot blame geography (identical), culture (shared), or ethnicity (same families on both sides). The only difference is which set of rules govern each side.

parameters.name: Chapter 2: Theories That Don't Work
parameters.description: Demolishing rival explanations for national prosperity

theories.name: Geography Hypothesis
theories.claim: Poor countries are poor because of bad geography - tropical climates, disease, infertile soil.
rebuttals: North and South Korea share the same peninsula. One is rich, one desperately poor.
Singapore sits on the equator and is one of the richest countries in the world.

The 'Reversal of Fortune': In 1500, the richest regions were Mexico (Aztec Empire), Peru (Inca Empire), and India (Mughal Empire). Today, these are middle-income or poor. Meanwhile, North America and Australia - sparsely populated 'backwaters' in 1500 - are now among the richest. If geography determined wealth, this reversal would be impossible.

theories.name: Culture Hypothesis
theories.claim: Some cultures value hard work, education, or thrift; others don't. Religion or ethnic attitudes explain prosperity.
rebuttals: North and South Koreans share identical culture, language, and history until 1945. The divergence is entirely institutional.
Japan was feudal and poor until the Meiji Restoration changed institutions. Culture didn't change overnight - institutions did.
Culture is often shaped by institutions, not the other way around. People respond to incentives.

theories.name: Ignorance Hypothesis
theories.claim: Poor countries have bad policies because their leaders don't know better. If we just advised them correctly, they'd reform.
rebuttals: Leaders of extractive regimes often know which policies would help their citizens but choose not to implement them - because inclusive policies would threaten their grip on power.
Robert Mugabe didn't destroy Zimbabwe's economy out of ignorance. He did it to reward loyalists and punish opponents.
The problem isn't knowledge; it's incentives created by extractive political institutions.

parameters.name: Chapter 3: Virtuous and Vicious Circles
parameters.description: How institutions reinforce themselves over time

config.chapterTitle: The Making of Prosperity and Poverty

virtuousCircle.mechanism: When political institutions are inclusive, they create economic institutions that spread opportunity. Prosperity then creates a larger middle class with stakes in maintaining inclusive institutions. They resist attempts to concentrate power.

viciousCircle.mechanism: When elites control political power, they design economic rules to benefit themselves. They use that wealth to entrench their political power further. Anyone who threatens the system is crushed.
viciousCircle.example: Colonial Latin America, where encomienda and hacienda systems persisted for centuries

creativeDestruction.definition: Schumpeter's term: new technologies and businesses replace old ones
creativeDestruction.insight: Extractive elites often oppose economic development - even though it would make the country richer - because growth requires creative destruction that threatens existing elites.
examples: Industrialisation empowered factory owners over landed aristocracy
Printing threatened the Church's monopoly on knowledge
historicalCases: Ottoman Empire banned the printing press for decades
Soviet Union couldn't generate sustained innovation despite educating millions of engineers

parameters.name: Chapter 4: Critical Junctures
parameters.description: Major events that create opportunities for institutional change

config.definition: A critical juncture is a major event that disrupts the existing balance of power and creates an opportunity for institutional change - for better or worse.
config.keyPrinciple: The outcome of a critical juncture depends on small initial differences in existing institutions.

blackDeath.event: Plague killed 30-50% of Europe's population. Labour became scarce.

westernEurope.mechanism: Peasants already had slightly more bargaining power (some free villages, some town charters). With labour scarce, peasants demanded wages and freedoms. This set the stage for more inclusive institutions over centuries.

easternEurope.mechanism: Landlords had more control over state apparatus. They responded by tightening serfdom - laws tied peasants to the land more strictly. Extractive institutions deepened. Eastern Europe remained poor for centuries longer.

blackDeath.lesson: Same shock, opposite outcomes - because small initial differences in institutional balance determined which way the juncture would tip.

atlanticTrade.question: Why England, Not Spain?
atlanticTrade.spain: The Crown monopolised trade revenues. Wealth flowed to the monarchy, strengthening absolutism.
atlanticTrade.england: Merchants and gentry (not just the king) participated in Atlantic trade. They grew wealthy and powerful enough to challenge the Crown - leading to the Glorious Revolution of 1688.
outcome1688: Secure property rights (the king couldn't arbitrarily seize assets)
Rule of law and independent courts
atlanticTrade.lesson: England's small initial difference - a slightly more empowered merchant class - became a huge divergence after the critical juncture of Atlantic trade.

parameters.name: Key Case Studies
parameters.description: Comparative examples for teaching the framework

cases.name: North Korea vs South Korea
cases.setup: Same people, same culture, same geography, same history until 1945. Divided by Cold War politics.

comparison.south: Initially authoritarian but gradually developed inclusive institutions. Now a wealthy democracy.
comparison.north: Totalitarian extractive institutions. One of the poorest countries on earth. Citizens starve while elites live in luxury.

cases.vividImage: Satellite photo at night: South Korea blazing with light; North Korea almost completely dark.

cases.name: East Germany vs West Germany
cases.setup: Same ethnic group, language, geography. Divided after WWII.

comparison.west: Liberal democracy, market economy, inclusive institutions - prosperity, innovation, civil rights
comparison.east: Soviet-style command economy, extractive political control - stagnation, surveillance state, brain drain

cases.aftermath: After reunification, the gap persisted for decades - institutional damage takes generations to repair.

cases.name: The Glorious Revolution (1688)
events: English Parliament overthrows King James II
William and Mary accept constitutional constraints
Parliament controls taxation; property rights secured; courts independent
cases.significance: Created the institutional foundation for the Industrial Revolution
cases.question: Why did the Industrial Revolution happen in England?
cases.answer: Not coal (Germany had coal). Not Protestant work ethic (Catholic Belgium industrialised quickly). Because England had institutions that rewarded innovation and protected inventors' profits.

parameters.name: Scholarly Critiques
parameters.description: Challenges to the thesis for stress-testing understanding

config.usage: Use LATE in session - only after core concept is solid

argument: Agrees institutions matter but argues Acemoglu and Robinson understate geography
Eurasia's east-west axis allowed crops and ideas to spread; Africa's north-south axis didn't
What causes good institutions in the first place? Maybe geography shaped which societies could develop them.
critiques.authorsResponse: Geography sets initial conditions but isn't destiny. The 'Reversal of Fortune' proves geography alone can't explain outcomes. Singapore, Hong Kong, and Botswana overcame geographic disadvantages with good institutions.

argument: Physical infrastructure (landlocked countries face trade barriers)
Global economic forces (debt crises, commodity price swings)
He points to China: authoritarian but growing rapidly. How does that fit?
critiques.authorsResponse: China's growth is extractive growth - like the Soviet Union's early growth. It can continue for a while by moving peasants to factories, but will eventually stall without inclusive institutions that enable creative destruction. They predict China will either transition to inclusive institutions or see growth falter.

critiques.description: China is the hardest case. Authoritarian, extractive political institutions - yet decades of rapid growth.

interpretations.argument: China has liberalised economically (some market mechanisms) while remaining extractive politically. Growth came from importing technology and mobilising labour. But without inclusive political institutions, China cannot sustain innovation-led growth. The Soviet Union grew fast in the 1950s-60s too - then collapsed.
Maybe hybrid models can work. Maybe authoritarian states can manage creative destruction if they're competent enough.

critiques.note: This is an open debate. Good for students to see that even strong theories have contested edges.

questions.question: If geography matters so little, why are so many tropical countries poor?
questions.tests: Whether they can articulate the institutional response

questions.question: If good institutions lead to prosperity, what stops every country from just adopting them?
questions.tests: Understanding of vicious circles and elite resistance

questions.question: North Korea and South Korea - same people, same culture. What does that tell us about the culture hypothesis?
questions.tests: Application of framework to refute culture hypothesis

questions.question: The Soviet Union grew fast for decades under extractive institutions. Does that disprove the thesis?
If you were advising a country with extractive institutions, what would you tell them to do? Why is that advice hard to follow?
questions.tests: Understanding of vicious circles and elite incentives

parameters.name: Opening Case Selection
parameters.description: Four opening puzzles to rotate for session variety

config.selectionRule: Based on minute value of session start time

options.opening: There's a city called Nogales, split by the US-Mexico border. Same people on both sides, same geography, same culture. But one side is three times richer. What do you think explains that?

Think about North and South Korea. Same people, same language, same history until 1945. Now one is among the richest countries on earth, the other among the poorest. There's a famous satellite photo at night - South Korea is blazing with light, North Korea is almost completely dark. What do you think explains that?

Here's something counterintuitive. In 1500, the richest places on earth were Mexico, Peru, India - the Aztec, Inca, Mughal empires. Meanwhile, North America and Australia were sparsely populated backwaters. Today it's completely reversed. What do you think happened?
Let me ask you something. Why did the Industrial Revolution happen in England and not, say, France or China? Both had smart people, resources, trade. What was different about England?

constraints.description: Tutor must ONLY use content from this spec - no invented facts beyond what is here
Establish core concept BEFORE introducing critiques - concept first, challenge later
Always introduce book, authors, and Nobel Prize before diving into content
Only introduce ONE critique per session, and only after 5-8 minutes when concept is solid
